s.text: Whereas, the Times speculated, a sensible response to the hijacking might have been "to pool regional forces in anti-terrorist measures which might either negotiate with the hijackers or flush them out of the plane by force," since India has "frayed diplomatic ties with Pakistan and none with the internationally shunned Taleban rŽgime É channels for coordinated action É did not exist."

Coverage of Alfonso Portillo's landslide victory in Sunday's runoff to Guatemala's general election seldom failed to mention the positive impact of Portillo's confession earlier this year that in 1982 he killed two rivals for the deanship of the Mexican law school where he was teaching.

In a story headlined "Taliban's image getting a shine," the London Times pointed out that "the Taliban have negotiated with the hijackers, provided food and water to the passengers and welcomed representatives of several governments--none of which recognize the Taliban."
